Explanation.para: The REXX program could not be read from the disk.

UserAction.para: Verify file's existence and make sure no other process has it locked.

SubMessage.Text: Failure during initialization: File is unreadable.
Failure during initialization: Program was not found.
Error writing output file .
Program cannot be run by this version of the REXX interpreter.
Encoded compiled program cannot be decoded.
Failure during initialization: Program needs to be tokenized. To run untokenized scripts you need a full version of Object REXX.

Explanation.para: The system interrupted the execution of your program because of an error or a user request.

UserAction.para: Trap interrupts via CALL ON HALT or SIGNAL ON HALT.

SubMessage.Text: Program interrupted with condition.

Explanation.para: While trying to execute a program, the language processor was unable to get the resources it needed to continue. For example, it could not get the space needed for its work areas or variables. The program that called the language processor might itself have already used up most of the available storage. Or a request for storage might have been for more than the implementation maximum.

A comment or literal string was started but never finished. This could be because the language processor detected:
The end of the program (or the end of the string in an INTERPRET instruction) without finding the ending "*/" for a comment or the ending quotation mark for a literal string
The end of the line for a literal string.

SubMessage.Text: Unmatched comment delimiter (/*) on line .
Unmatched single quote ().
Unmatched double quote ().

Explanation.para: At least one WHEN construct (and possibly an OTHERWISE clause) is expected within a SELECT instruction. This message is issued if any other instruction is found or there is no WHEN construct before the OTHERWISE or all WHEN expressions are false and an OTHERWISE is not present. A common cause of this error is if you forget the DO and END around the list of instructions following a WHEN. For example:
Explanation.programlisting:
WRONG RIGHT
Select Select When a=c then When a=c then DO Say 'A equals C' Say 'A equals C' exit exit Otherwise nop end end Otherwise nop end

UserAction.para: Look for any instruction other than WHEN (or for any missing WHEN construct before the OTHERWISE) in the SELECT construct.

SubMessage.Text: SELECT on line requires WHEN.
SELECT on line requires WHEN, OTHERWISE, or END.
All WHEN expressions of SELECT are false; OTHERWISE expected.

Explanation.para: A THEN or an ELSE clause was found that does not match a corresponding IF or WHEN clause. This often occurs because of a missing END or DO...END in the THEN part of a complex IF...THEN...ELSE construction. For example:
Explanation.programlisting:
WRONG RIGHT
If a=c then do; If a=c then do; Say EQUALS Say EQUALS exit exit else end Say NOT EQUALS else Say NOT EQUALS

UserAction.para: Look for a missing END or DO...END in the THEN part of a complex IF...THEN...ELSE construction.

SubMessage.Text: THEN has no corresponding IF or WHEN clause.
ELSE has no corresponding THEN clause.

Explanation.para: A WHEN or OTHERWISE was found outside of a SELECT construction. You might have accidentally enclosed the instruction in a DO...END construction by leaving out an END, or you might have tried to branch to it with a SIGNAL instruction (which does not work because the SELECT is then ended).

SubMessage.Text: WHEN has no corresponding SELECT.
OTHERWISE has no corresponding SELECT.

Explanation.para: More ENDs were found in your program than DO, LOOP, or SELECT instructions, or the ENDs did not match the DO, LOOP, or SELECT instructions. This message also occurs if you try to transfer control into the middle of a loop using SIGNAL. In this case, the language processor does not expect the END because it did not process the previous DO instruction. Remember also that SIGNAL deactivates any current loops, so it cannot transfer control from one place inside a loop to another.

Another cause for this message is placing an END immediately after a THEN or ELSE subkeyword or specifying a name on the END keyword that does not match the name following DO or LOOP. Putting the name of the control variable on ENDs that close repetitive loops can also help locate this kind of error.

SubMessage.Text: END has no corresponding DO, LOOP, or SELECT.
Symbol following END () must match block specification name () on line or be omitted.
END corresponding to block on line must not have a symbol following it because there is no LABEL or control variable; found .
END must not immediately follow THEN.
END must not immediately follow ELSE.
Symbol following END () must match LABEL of SELECT specification () on line or be omitted.
END corresponding to SELECT on line must not have a symbol following it because there is no LABEL; found .

Explanation.para: Your program exceeds the nesting level limit for control structures (for example, DO...END and IF...THEN...ELSE). This could be because of a looping INTERPRET instruction, such as:

These lines loop until they exceed the nesting level limit and the language processor issues this message. Similarly, a recursive subroutine or internal function that does not end correctly can loop until it causes this message.

SubMessage.Text: Insufficient control stack space; cannot continue execution.

Explanation.para: A character was found outside a literal (quoted) string that is not a whitespace character or one of the valid alphanumeric and special characters.

SubMessage.Text: Incorrect character in program (''X).

Explanation.para: At the end of the program or the string for an INTERPRET instruction, a DO, LOOP, or SELECT instruction was found without a matching END or an IF clause that is not followed by a THEN clause. Putting the name of the control variable on each END closing a controlled loop can help locate this kind of error.

SubMessage.Text: DO instruction on line requires matching END.
SELECT instruction on line requires matching END.
THEN on line must be followed by an instruction.
ELSE on line must be followed by an instruction.

Subcodes.SubMessage: / 14 005 725 Rexx Warning Error_Incomplete_do_loop DO or LOOP instruction on line requires matching END.

SubMessage.Text: OTHERWISE on line requires matching END.

Explanation.para: Hexadecimal strings must not have leading or trailing whitespace characters and whitespace can only be embedded at byte boundaries. Only the digits 0-9 and the letters a-f and A-F are allowed. The following are valid hexadecimal strings:
Binary strings can have whitespace only at the boundaries of groups of four binary digits. Only the digits 0 and 1 are allowed. These are valid binary strings:

You might have mistyped one of the digits, for example, typing a letter O instead of the number 0. Or you might have used the one-character symbol X or B (the name of the variable X or B, respectively) after a literal string when the string is not intended as a hexadecimal or binary specification. In this case, use the explicit concatenation operator (||) to concatenate the string to the value of the symbol.

UserAction.para: Use the explicit concatenation operator || in situations where X or B is intended to represent a variable.

SubMessage.Text: Incorrect location of whitespace character in position in hexadecimal string.
Incorrect location of whitespace character in position in binary string.
Only 0-9, a-f, A-F, and whitespace characters are valid in a hexadecimal string; found .
Only 0, 1, and whitespace characters are valid in a binary string; found .
Hexidecimal strings must be grouped in units that are multiples of two characters.
Binary strings must be grouped in units that are multiples of four characters.

Explanation.para: A SIGNAL instruction has been executed or an event for which a trap was set with SIGNAL ON has occurred, and the language processor could not find the label specified. You might have mistyped the label or forgotten to include it.

SubMessage.Text: Label not found.

Explanation.para: A PROCEDURE instruction was encountered at an incorrect position. This could occur because no internal routines are active or because the PROCEDURE instruction was not the first instruction processed after the CALL instruction or function call. One cause for this error is dropping through to an internal routine, rather than calling it with a CALL instruction or a function call.

SubMessage.Text: PROCEDURE is valid only when it is the first instruction executed after an internal CALL or function invocation.
INTERPRET data must not contain PROCEDURE.

Explanation.para: A THEN clause must follow each REXX IF or WHEN clause. The language processor found another clause before it found a THEN clause.

SubMessage.Text: IF instruction on line requires matching THEN clause.
WHEN instruction on line requires matching THEN clause.

Explanation.para: A symbol or string was expected after the CALL or SIGNAL keywords but none was found. You might have omitted the string or symbol or inserted a special character (such as a parenthesis).

SubMessage.Text: String or symbol expected after ADDRESS keyword.
String or symbol expected after CALL keyword.
String or symbol expected after NAME keyword.
String or symbol expected after SIGNAL keyword.
String or symbol expected after TRACE keyword.
String or symbol expected after PARSE keyword.
String or symbol expected after ::CLASS keyword.
String or symbol expected after ::METHOD keyword.
String or symbol expected after ::ROUTINE keyword.
String or symbol expected after ::REQUIRES keyword.
String expected after EXTERNAL keyword.
String or symbol expected after METACLASS keyword.
String or symbol expected after SUBCLASS keyword.
String or symbol expected after INHERIT keyword.
String or symbol expected after tilde (~).
String or symbol expected after superclass colon (:).
String or symbol expected after STREAM keyword.
String or symbol expected after MIXINCLASS keyword.
String or symbol expected as ::ATTRIBUTE directive name.
String or symbol expected as ::CONSTANT directive name.
String or symbol expected as ::CONSTANT value.
String or symbol expected as DIGITS value.
String or symbol expected as FUZZ value.
String or symbol expected as TRACE value.
String or symbol expected as ::RESOURCE directive name.
String or symbol expected after ::RESOURCE END keyword.
String or symbol expected after keyword.
Symbol or string expected as ::ANNOTATE attribute value; found .
Symbol or string expected as ::ANNOTATE attribute value.
Symbol or string expected after keyword.

Explanation.para: A symbol is expected after CALL ON, CALL OFF, END, ITERATE, LEAVE, NUMERIC, PARSE, SIGNAL ON, or SIGNAL OFF. Also, a list of symbols or variable references is expected after DROP, EXPOSE, and PROCEDURE EXPOSE. Either there was no symbol when one was required or the language processor found another token.

SubMessage.Text: Symbol expected after DROP keyword.
Symbol expected after EXPOSE keyword.
Symbol expected after PARSE keyword.
Symbol expected after PARSE VAR.
NUMERIC must be followed by one of the keywords DIGITS, FORM, or FUZZ; found .
Symbol expected after ( of a variable reference.
Symbol expected after LEAVE keyword.
Symbol expected after ITERATE keyword.
Symbol expected after END keyword.
Symbol expected after ON keyword.
Symbol expected after OFF keyword.
Symbol expected after USE ARG.
Symbol expected after RAISE keyword.
Symbol expected after USER keyword.
Symbol expected after ::.
Symbol expected after superclass colon (:).
Symbol expected after LABEL keyword.
Symbol expected as ::ANNOTATE attribute name; found .
Symbol expected after NAMESPACE keyword.
Symbol expected as a class name of qualified class name.
Symbol expected as a routine name of qualified CALL instruction.
Symbol expected as a name of namespace-qualified symbol.
Symbol expected for the ::ANNOTATE type.
Symbol expected after the FORM keyword.
Symbol expected after the DELEGATE keyword.
Symbol expected after USE LOCAL.
Symbol expected as an indirect variable name; found .
Symbol expected after keyword.
Simple variable or stem symbol expected after > or < prefix operator; found .
Simple variable or stem symbol expected after > or < USE ARG reference operator; found .
Stem symbol expected after STEM keyword.
Symbol expected after WITH keyword.
Symbol expected after COUNTER keyword.

Message.Text: Invalid data on end of clause.

Explanation.para: A clause such as SELECT or NOP is followed by a token other than a comment.

SubMessage.Text: Data must not follow the NOP keyword; found .
Data must not follow the SELECT keyword; found .
Data must not follow the NAME keyword; found .
Data must not follow the condition name; found .
Data must not follow the SIGNAL label name; found .
Data must not follow the TRACE setting; found .
Data must not follow the LEAVE control variable name; found .
Data must not follow the ITERATE control variable name; found .
Data must not follow the END control variable name; found .
Data must not follow the NUMERIC FORM specification; found .
Data must not follow the GUARD OFF specification; found .
Data must not follow the ::CONSTANT value; found .
Data must not follow the ::RESOURCE directive; found .

Explanation.para: A literal string contains character codes that are not valid. This might be because some characters are not possible, or because the character set is extended and certain character combinations are not allowed.

SubMessage.Text: Incorrect character string (''X).
Incorrect double-byte character.

Explanation.para: A data string (that is, the result of an expression) contains character codes that are not valid. This might be because some characters are not possible, or because the character set is extended and certain character combinations are not allowed.

SubMessage.Text: Incorrect data string (''X).

Explanation.para:
This message is issued when:
The option on a TRACE instruction or the argument to the built-in function does not start with A, C, E, F, I, L, N, O, or R.
In interactive debugging, you entered a number that is not a whole number.

SubMessage.Text: TRACE request letter must be one of ACEFILNOR; found .
Numeric TRACE requests are valid only from interactive debugging.

Explanation.para: An unexpected token was found at his position of an instruction where a particular subkeyword was expected. For example, in a NUMERIC instruction, the second token must be DIGITS, FUZZ, or FORM.

SubMessage.Text: CALL ON must be followed by one of the keywords ERROR, FAILURE, HALT, NOTREADY, USER, or ANY; found .
CALL OFF must be followed by one of the keywords ERROR, FAILURE, HALT, NOTREADY, USER, or ANY; found .
SIGNAL ON must be followed by one of the keywords ERROR, FAILURE, HALT, LOSTDIGITS, NOTREADY, NOMETHOD, NOSTRING, NOVALUE, SYNTAX, USER, or ANY; found .
SIGNAL OFF must be followed by one of the keywords ERROR, FAILURE, HALT, LOSTDIGITS, NOTREADY, NOMETHOD, NOSTRING, NOVALUE, SYNTAX, USER, or ANY; found .
NUMERIC FORM must be followed by one of the keywords SCIENTIFIC or ENGINEERING; found .
PARSE must be followed by one of the keywords ARG, LINEIN, PULL, SOURCE, VALUE, VAR, or VERSION; found .
NUMERIC must be followed by one of the keywords DIGITS, FORM, or FUZZ; found .
PROCEDURE must be followed by the keyword EXPOSE or nothing; found .
Unknown keyword on ::CLASS directive; found .
Unknown keyword on ::METHOD directive; found .
Unknown keyword on ::ROUTINE directive; found .
Unknown keyword on ::REQUIRES directive; found .
USE must be followed by the keyword ARG or LOCAL; found .
CALL ON condition must be followed by the keyword NAME; found .
SIGNAL ON condition must be followed by the keyword NAME; found .
RAISE must be followed by one of the keywords ERROR, FAILURE, HALT, LOSTDIGITS, NOMETHOD, NOSTRING, NOTREADY, NOVALUE, PROPAGATE, SYNTAX, or USER; found .
Unknown keyword on RAISE instruction; found .
Duplicate DESCRIPTION keyword found.
Duplicate ADDITIONAL or ARRAY keyword found.
Duplicate RETURN or EXIT keyword found.
GUARD ON or GUARD OFF must be followed by the keyword WHEN; found .
GUARD must be followed by the keyword ON or OFF; found .
Unknown keyword on FORWARD instruction; found .
Duplicate TO keyword found.
Duplicate ARGUMENTS or ARRAY keyword found.
Duplicate RETURN or CONTINUE keyword found.
Duplicate CLASS keyword found.
Duplicate MESSAGE keyword found.
SELECT must be followed by the keyword LABEL or CASE; found .
Unknown keyword on ::OPTIONS directive; found .
Unknown keyword on ::ATTRIBUTE directive; found .
Unknown keyword on ::RESOURCE directive; found .
Unknown keyword following ; found .
Unknown keyword on ::ANNOTATE directive; found .
USE STRICT must be followed by the keyword ARG; found .
Duplicate INPUT keyword found.
Duplicate OUTPUT keyword found.
Duplicate ERROR keyword found.
Acceptable ADDRESS WITH I/O types are STEM, STREAM, and USING; found .
WITH must be followed by one of the keywords INPUT, OUTPUT, or ERROR; found .

Explanation.para:
An expression was found that did not evaluate to a whole number or is greater than the limit (the default is 999,999,999 for 32-bit system and 999,999,999,999,999,999 for 64-bit systems):
The positional patterns in parsing templates (including variable positional patterns)
The operand to the right of the power operator
The values of exprr and exprf in the DO and LOOP instructions
The values given for DIGITS or FUZZ in the NUMERIC instruction
The number used in the option of the TRACE setting
This error is also raised if the value is not permitted (for example, a negative repetition count in a DO instruction), or the division performed during an integer divide or remainder operation does not result in a whole number.

SubMessage.Text: Value of repetition count expression in DO or LOOP instruction must be zero or a positive whole number; found .
Value of FOR expression in DO or LOOP instruction must be zero or a positive whole number; found .
Positional pattern of PARSE template must be a whole number; found .
DIGITS value must be a positive whole number; found .
FUZZ value must be zero or a positive whole number; found .
Number used in TRACE setting must be a whole number; found .
Operand to the right of the power operator (**) must be a whole number; found .
Result of % operation did not result in a whole number.
Result of // operation did not result in a whole number.
Result of a method call did not result in a whole number; found .
Result of a COMPARETO method call did not result in a whole number; found .
Result of a COMPARE method call did not result in a whole number; found .
Stem element 0 is not a whole number; found .

Explanation.para: A syntax error was found in a DO or LOOP instruction. You probably used BY, TO, FOR, WHILE, or UNTIL twice, used a WHILE and an UNTIL, or used BY, TO, or FOR when there is no control variable specified.

SubMessage.Text: Only one WHILE or UNTIL condition can be used on the same loop.
Incorrect data following FOREVER keyword on the loop; found .
DO or LOOP keyword can be specified only once.
No INDEX or ITEM control variable specified on a WITH loop.
OVER keyword expected for a WITH loop.
COUNTER keyword not allowd on a simple DO instruction.

Explanation.para: A LEAVE or ITERATE instruction was found at an incorrect position. Either no loop was active, or the name specified on the instruction did not match the control variable of any active loop. Note that internal routine calls and the INTERPRET instruction protect loops by making them inactive. Therefore, for example, a LEAVE instruction in a subroutine cannot affect a DO loop in the calling routine. You probably tried to use the SIGNAL instruction to transfer control within or into a loop. Because a SIGNAL instruction ends all active loops, any ITERATE or LEAVE instruction causes this message.

SubMessage.Text: LEAVE is valid only within a repetitive loop or labeled block instruction.
ITERATE is valid only within a repetitive loop.
Symbol following LEAVE () must either match the label of a current loop or block instruction.
Symbol following ITERATE () must either match the label of a current loop or be omitted.
Symbol following ITERATE () does not match a repetitive block instruction.

Explanation.para: The environment name specified on the ADDRESS instruction is longer than permitted for the system under which the interpreter is running.

SubMessage.Text: Environment name exceeds characters; found .

Explanation.para: A variable name, label name, literal (quoted) string has exceeded the allowed limit of 250 characters. The limit for names includes any substitutions. A possible cause of this error is if you use a period (.) in a name, causing an unexpected substitution. Leaving off an ending quotation mark for a literal string, or putting a single quotation mark in a string, can cause this error because several clauses can be included in the string. For example, write the string 'don't' as 'don't' or "don't".

SubMessage.Text: Name exceeds 250 characters: .
Literal string exceeds 250 characters: .
Hexadecimal literal string exceeds 250 characters .
Binary literal string exceeds 250 characters .

Explanation.para: A variable was found whose name begins with a numeric digit or a period. You cannot assign a value to such a variable because you could then redefine numeric constants.

SubMessage.Text: A value cannot be assigned to a number; found .
Variable symbol must not start with a number; found .
Variable symbol must not start with a .; found .

Explanation.para: The result of an expression was found not to be valid in the context in which it was used.

UserAction.para: Check for an illegal FUZZ or DIGITS value in a NUMERIC instruction. FUZZ must not become larger than DIGITS.

SubMessage.Text: Value of NUMERIC DIGITS () must exceed value of NUMERIC FUZZ ().
Value of NUMERIC DIGITS () must not exceed .
Incorrect expression result following VALUE keyword of ADDRESS instruction.
Incorrect expression result following VALUE keyword of SIGNAL instruction.
Incorrect expression result following VALUE keyword of TRACE instruction.
Incorrect expression result following SYNTAX keyword of RAISE instruction.

Explanation.para: An expression was found in an IF, WHEN, WHILE, or UNTIL phrase that did not result in a 0 or 1. Any value operated on by a logical operator must result in a 0 or 1. For example, the phrase "If result then exit rc" fails if result has a value other than 0 or 1.

SubMessage.Text: Value of expression following IF keyword must be exactly 0 or 1; found .
Value of expression following WHEN keyword must be exactly 0 or 1; found .
Value of expression following WHILE keyword must be exactly 0 or 1; found .
Value of expression following UNTIL keyword must be exactly 0 or 1; found .
Value of expression to the left of the logical operator must be exactly 0 or 1; found .
Value of logical list expression element must be exactly 0 or 1; found .
Logical value must be exactly 0 or 1; found .
Value of expression following GUARD keyword must be exactly 0 or 1; found .
Authorization return value must be exactly 0 or 1; found .
Property logical value must be exactly 0, 1, true, or false; found .
SELECT CASE comparison result must be exactly 0 or 1; found .
Supplier AVAILABLE method did not return exactly 0 or 1; found .

Explanation.para:
An expression contains a grammatical error. Possible causes:
An expression is missing when one is required
You ended an expression with an operator
You specified, in an expression, two operators next to one another with nothing in between them
You did not specify a right parenthesis when one was required
You used special characters (such as operators) in an intended character expression without enclosing them in quotation marks

UserAction.para: Check for special characters (such as operators) in an intended character expression that are not enclosed in quotes.

SubMessage.Text: Incorrect expression detected at .
Prefix operator is not followed by an expression term.
Missing conditional expression following IF keyword.
Missing conditional expression following WHEN keyword.
Missing initial expression for DO or LOOP control variable.
Missing expression following BY keyword.
Missing expression following TO keyword.
Missing expression following FOR keyword.
Missing expression following WHILE keyword.
Missing expression following UNTIL keyword.
Missing expression following OVER keyword.
Missing expression following INTERPRET keyword.
Missing expression following OPTIONS keyword.
Missing expression following VALUE keyword of an ADDRESS instruction.
Missing expression following VALUE keyword of a SIGNAL instruction.
Missing expression following VALUE keyword of a TRACE instruction.
Missing expression following VALUE keyword of a NUMERIC FORM instruction.
Missing expression following assignment instruction.
Operator is not followed by an expression term.
Missing expression following GUARD keyword.
Missing expression following DESCRIPTION keyword of a RAISE instruction.
Missing expression following ADDITIONAL keyword of a RAISE instruction.
Missing ( on expression list of the ARRAY keyword.
Missing expression following TO keyword of a FORWARD instruction.
Missing expression following ARGUMENTS keyword of a FORWARD instruction.
Missing expression following MESSAGE keyword of a FORWARD instruction.
Missing expression following CLASS keyword of a FORWARD instruction.
Missing expression in logical expression list.
Invalid or missing expression following = token of a USE ARG instruction.
Missing expression following ( of parse template.
Missing expression for calculated CALL name.
Missing expression following CASE keyword of a SELECT instruction.
Missing expression in WHEN case expression list.
Missing expression following keyword of a instruction.
Missing expression on ::CONSTANT directive.

Explanation.para: A matched parenthesis or bracket was found within an expression. There are more left parentheses than right parentheses or more left brackets than right brackets. To include a single parenthesis in a command, enclose it in quotation marks.

SubMessage.Text: Left parenthesis ( in position on line requires a corresponding right parenthesis ).
Square bracket [ in position on line requires a corresponding right square bracket ].

Explanation.para: Either a comma was found outside a function invocation, or there are too many right parentheses or right square brackets in an expression. To include a comma in a character expression, enclose it in quotation marks. For example, write the instruction:
Explanation.programlisting: Say Enter A, B, or C
Explanation.para: as follows:

SubMessage.Text: Unexpected ,.
Unmatched ) in expression.
Unexpected ].

Explanation.para: A special character that is not allowed within a parsing template (for example, "%") has been found, or the syntax of a variable pattern is incorrect (that is, no symbol was found after a left parenthesis). This message is also issued if you omit the WITH subkeyword in a PARSE VALUE instruction.

SubMessage.Text: Incorrect PARSE template detected at .
Incorrect PARSE position detected at .
PARSE VALUE instruction requires WITH keyword.
Missing PARSE relative position.

Explanation.para: The expression is too complex to be evaluated by the language processor.

An incorrect call to a routine was found. Possible causes:
You passed incorrect data (arguments) to the built-in or external routine.
You passed too many arguments to the built-in, external, or internal routine.
The external routine called was not compatible with the language processor.
If you did not try to call a routine, you might have a symbol or a string adjacent to a "(" when you meant it to be separated by a blank or other operator. The language processor would treat this as a function call. For example, write TIME(4+5) as follows: TIME*(4+5)

SubMessage.Text: External routine failed.
Not enough arguments in invocation of ; minimum expected is .
Too many arguments in invocation of ; maximum expected is .
Missing argument in invocation of ; argument is required.
argument must be a number; found .
argument must be a whole number; found .
argument must be zero or positive; found .
argument must be positive; found .
argument 2, , is not in the format described by argument 3, .
argument must not be a null string.
argument must be a single character or null; found .
argument must be a single character; found .
argument must be a binary string; found .
argument must be a hexadecimal string; found .
argument must be a valid symbol; found .
argument 1 must be a valid stream name; found .
argument must be a character class name or a single character; found .
conversion to format is not allowed.
RANDOM difference between argument 1 () and argument 2 () must not exceed 999,999,999.
RANDOM argument 1 () must be less than or equal to argument 2 ().
SOURCELINE argument 1 () must be less than or equal to the number of lines in the program ().
X2D argument 1 cannot be expressed as a whole number; found .
argument must be a single non-alphanumeric character or the null string; found .
argument , , is a format incompatible with the separator specified in argument .
Result returned by is longer than : .
argument must not exceed the whole number limit.
argument must be in the range 0-99; found .
argument must be one of ; found .
TRACE setting letter must be one of ACEFILNOR; found .
argument must be a single-dimensional array; found .
argument must have a string value; found .
Unknown VALUE function variable environment selector; found .
cannot be used with QUEUE:.
Cannot read from a write-only property.
Cannot write to a read-only property or typelib element.
Invalid native function signature specification.
Argument must have a stem object or stem name value; found .
argument must be one of ; found .
Argument () must be greater than argument ().
Stem argument does not have a valid count for element 0.
The operation is outside the size of the stem array ().
Stem element at position is not set.

Explanation.para: A term in an arithmetic expression is not a valid number or has an exponent outside the allowed range of whole number range.
You might have mistyped a variable name, or included an arithmetic operator in a character expression without putting it in quotation marks.

SubMessage.Text: Nonnumeric value () used in arithmetic operation.
Nonnumeric value () used with prefix operator.
Value of TO expression of DO or LOOP instruction must be numeric; found .
Value of BY expression of DO or LOOP instruction must be numeric; found .
Value of control variable expression of DO or LOOP instruction must be numeric; found .
Exponent exceeds digits; found .
Value of RAISE instruction SYNTAX expression must be numeric; found .

Explanation.para: The result of an arithmetic operation requires an exponent that is greater than the platform limit of nine digits.
This error can occur during the evaluation of an expression (often as a result of trying to divide a number by 0) or while stepping a loop control variable.

SubMessage.Text: Arithmetic overflow detected at: .
Arithmetic underflow detected at: .
Arithmetic overflow; divisor must not be zero.
Arithmetic overflow; exponent () exceeds digits.
Arithmetic underflow; exponent () exceeds digits.
Arithmetic underflow; zero raised to a negative power.

Explanation.para:
A function has been invoked within an expression or a subroutine has been invoked by a CALL, but it cannot be found. Possible reasons:
The specified label is not in the program
It is not the name of a built-in function
The language processor could not locate it externally
Check if you mistyped the name.

If you did not try to call a routine, you might have put a symbol or string adjacent to a "(" when you meant it to be separated by a blank or another operator. The language processor then treats it as a function call. For example, write the string 3(4+5) as 3*(4+5).

SubMessage.Text: Could not find routine .
Could not find file for ::REQUIRES.
Routine not found in namespace .

Message.Text: Function or message did not return data.

Explanation.para: The language processor called an external routine within an expression. The routine seemed to end without error, but it did not return data for use in the expression.
You might have specified the name of a program that is not intended for use as a REXX function. Call it as a command or subroutine instead.

SubMessage.Text: No data returned from function .

Message.Text: No data specified on function RETURN.

Explanation.para: A REXX program has been called as a function, but returned without passing back any data.

SubMessage.Text: Data expected on RETURN instruction because routine was called as a function.

Explanation.para: Within an ARG, DROP, EXPOSE, PARSE, PULL, or PROCEDURE instruction, the syntax of a variable reference (a variable whose value is to be used, indicated by its name being enclosed in parentheses) is incorrect. The right parenthesis that must immediately follow the variable name might be missing or the variable name might be misspelled.

SubMessage.Text: Extra token () found in variable reference list; ) expected.
Missing ) in variable reference.
Extra token () found in USE ARG variable reference; , or end of instruction expected.

Explanation.para: A label was used in the expression being evaluated for an INTERPRET instruction or in an expression entered during interactive debugging.

UserAction.para: Remove the label from the interpreted data.

SubMessage.Text: INTERPRET data must not contain labels; found .

Explanation.para: The language processor stopped processing the program because a system service, such as stream input or output or the manipulation of the external data queue, has failed to work correctly.

SubMessage.Text: Failure in system service: .

Explanation.para: A severe error was detected in the language processor or execution process during internal self-consistency checks.

SubMessage.Text: Interpretation error: unexpected failure initializing the interpreter.
Interpretation error: unmatched .

Explanation.para: An internal interpreter error occured: a switch() statement couldn't match any of its case statements.
An argument passed to a method, function, or routine was not valid.

Explanation.para: An instruction was expecting either a single Rexx variable symbol or a message term to be used for an assignment.

SubMessage.Text: The USE instruction requires a comma-separated list of variables or assignment message terms.
The PARSE instruction was expecting a variable or a message term.

Explanation.para: An external class, method, or routine (specified with the EXTERNAL option on a ::CLASS, ::METHOD, or ::ROUTINE directive, or as a second argument on a NEW message to the Method class) cannot be found.

SubMessage.Text: Unable to find external class .
Unable to find external method .
Unable to find external routine .

Explanation.para: A message term requires a result object, but the method did not return one.

SubMessage.Text: Message did not return a result.
An unknown OLE error occurred (HRESULT=).

Explanation.para: An unexpected OLE error occurred. HRESULT contains the original error code provided by OLE.

SubMessage.Text: Cannot convert OLE VARIANT to REXX object: The conversion of the VARIANT type into a REXX object failed.
Cannot convert REXX object to OLE VARIANT: The conversion of into a VARIANT failed.
The number of elements provided to the method or property is different from the number of parameters accepted by it.
One of the parameters is not a valid VARIANT type.
OLE exception: .

Explanation.para: The OLE object reported an exception. It provides a code number, the source of the exception and a description of the exception.

SubMessage.Text: The requested method does not exist, or you tried to set the value of a read-only property.
One of the parameters could not be coerced to the desired type.
One or more of the parameters could not be coerced to the desired type. The first parameter with incorrect type is argument .
A required parameter was omitted.
Could not create OLE instance.

Explanation.para: The creation of the OLE object failed, possible causes: OLE object does not support automation interface or its initialization failed.

SubMessage.Text: The object invoked has disconnected from its clients.

Explanation.para: The specified method, built-in function, or external routine exists, but you used it incorrectly.

Explanation.para:
RXSUBCOM accepts the following parameters:
To register a subcommand handler: RXSUBCOM REGISTER Environment_Name Dll_Name Procedure_Name
To query the existence of a specific subcommand handler: RXSUBCOM QUERY [Environment_Name [Dll_Name]]
To drop a subcommand handler: RXSUBCOM DROP Environment_Name [Dll_Name]
To load a subcommand handler from disk: RXSUBCOM LOAD Environment_Name [Dll_Name]

UserAction.para: Check the RXSUBCOM parameters and retry the command.

SubMessage.Text: The RXSUBCOM parameter REGISTER is incorrect.

Explanation.para:
RXSUBCOM REGISTER requires the following parameters:
RXSUBCOM REGISTER Environment_Name Dll_Name Procedure_Name
Environment_Name
is the name of the subcommand handler.
. Dll_Name
is the name of the file containing the subcommand handler routine.
. Procedure_Name
is the name of the procedure that REXX calls as a subcommand handler.

UserAction.para: Check the RXSUBCOM parameters and retry the command.

SubMessage.Text: The RXSUBCOM parameter DROP is incorrect.

Explanation.para:
RXSUBCOM DROP requires that the subcommand handler name be specified.
RXSUBCOM DROP Environment_Name [Dll_Name]
Environment_Name
is the name of the subcommand handler.
. Dll_Name
is the name of the file containing the subcommand handler routine (optional).

UserAction.para: Check the RXSUBCOM parameters and retry the command.

SubMessage.Text: The RXSUBCOM parameter LOAD is incorrect.

Explanation.para:
RXSUBCOM LOAD requires that the subcommand handler name be specified.
RXSUBCOM LOAD Environment_Name [Dll_Name]
Environment_Name
is the name of the subcommand handler.
. Dll_Name
is the name of the file containing the subcommand handler routine (optional).

UserAction.para: Check the RXSUBCOM parameters and retry the command.

SubMessage.Text: The REXX rxapi queuing system is not available.
The size of the data is incorrect.

Explanation.para: The data supplied to the RXQUEUE command is too long. The RXQUEUE program accepts data records containing 0 - 65472 bytes. A record exceeded the allowable limits.

SubMessage.Text: Storage for data queues is exhausted.

Explanation.para: The queuing system is out of memory. No more storage is available to store queued data.

UserAction.para: Delete some queues or remove queued data from the system. Then retry your request.

SubMessage.Text: The name %1 is not a valid queue name.

Explanation.para: The queue name contains an invalid character. Only the following characters can appear in queue names:

UserAction.para: Change the queue name and retry the command.

SubMessage.Text: The queue access mode is not correct.

Explanation.para: An internal error occurred in RXQUEUE. The RXQUEUE program tried to access a queue with an incorrect access mode. Correct access modes are LIFO and FIFO.

SubMessage.Text: The queue %1 does not exist.

Explanation.para: The command attempted to access a nonexistent queue.

UserAction.para: Create the queue and try again, or use a queue that has been created.

SubMessage.Text: The RXSUBCOM parameter QUERY is incorrect.

Explanation.para:
RXSUBCOM QUERY requires the environment name be specified.
RXSUBCOM QUERY Environment_Name [Dll_Name]
Environment_Name
is the name of the subcommand handler.
. Dll_Name
is the name of the file containing the subcommand handler routine (optional).

UserAction.para: Check the RXSUBCOM parameters and retry the command.

SubMessage.Text: The REXXC command parameters are incorrect.

Explanation.para:
The REXXC utility was invoked with zero or more than three parameters. REXXC accepts the following parameters:
To check the syntax of a REXX program: REXXC Program_name [-s]
To convert a REXX program into a sourceless executable file: REXXC Program_name Output_file_name [-s]
The -s option will suppress the copyright banner.

UserAction.para: Check the REXXC parameters and retry the command.

SubMessage.Text: Output file name must be different from input file name.
SYNTAX: REXXC InProgramName [OutProgramName] [/S].
Without OutProgramName REXXC only performs a syntax check.
The syntax of the command is incorrect.
System error occurred while processing the command.
SYNTAX: REXXC InProgramName [OutProgramName] [-s].
